title: “This seems less like an attempted coup and more like a dramatic family feud”—Jordan’s royal ruckus
summary:
Also on the daily podcast: India’s revealing billionaires list and a Vancouver indigenous group with high-rise ambitions“This seems less like an attempted coup and more like a dramatic family feud”—Jordan’s royal ruckusPRESSURE ON THE king’s half-brother may represent a mere family feud, but Prince Hamzah’s complaints resonate with the country’s people.
We ask what will happen next.
Study the fast-growing list of India’s billionaires: who has joined it and who has left are signs of the country’s shifting economy.
And an indigenous group’s tall order in Vancouver’s property market.
Runtime: 21minListen on: Apple Podcasts | Spotify | Google | Stitcher | TuneInFor full access to print, digital and audio editions of The Economist, subscribe here www.economist.com/intelligenceoffer
paragraphs: Also on the daily podcast: India’s revealing billionaires list and a Vancouver indigenous group with high-rise ambitions
“This seems less like an attempted coup and more like a dramatic family feud”—Jordan’s royal ruckus

PRESSURE ON THE king’s half-brother may represent a mere family feud, but Prince Hamzah’s complaints resonate with the country’s people. We ask what will happen next. Study the fast-growing list of India’s billionaires: who has joined it and who has left are signs of the country’s shifting economy. And an indigenous group’s tall order in Vancouver’s property market. Runtime: 21min
